By Krull-Schmidt, an indecomposable of ${\mathsf{{F}}}_p^s$ is also an indecomposable of ${\mathsf{{F}}}_q^r$.
The M\"obius inversion of $\alpha$ is therefore positive.
\end{proof}

\begin{ex}
\label{ex:picard}
Suppose ${\mathsf{C}} = {\mathsf{Rep}}({\mathbb Z})$.
Consider two objects $a, b \in {\mathsf{C}}$, where $a : {\mathsf{k}}^2 \to {\mathsf{k}}^2$ is the Picard monodromy given by the matrix
	$
	\begin{bmatrix}
	1 & 1 \\
	0 & 1
	\end{bmatrix}
	$,
and $b : {\mathsf{k}} \to {\mathsf{k}}$ is the identity.
Both objects are indecomposable.
Let ${\mathsf{{F}}}$ be the $\{5, 15\}$-constructible module with
${\mathsf{{F}}}(p) = a$, for $5 \leq p < 15$.
Let ${\mathsf{{G}}}$ be the $\{ 3, 5, 17 \}$-constructible persistence module with the following specification:

nexttext:
\section{Concluding Remarks}
\label{sec:end}


Semicontintuiy is a one way statement of stability:
The persistence diagram of a persistence module lives on in the persistence
diagram of each nearby persistence module.
Bottleneck stability of CSEH is a two way statement of stability:
The persistence diagram of a persistence module is essentially the same
as the persistence diagram of each nearby persistence module.
Such a two way statement of stability should exist
whenever ${\mathsf{C}}$ is a semisimple category.

Persistence is used to study the shape of data.
However, torsion is ignored because one is forced to compute homology 
with coefficients in a field.
Our approach allows for the study of persistent torsion in data.

The flexibility of ${\mathsf{C}}$ should allow for the encoding of more structure in data.
Consider, for example, time series data.
Let $P = \{ p_1, p_2, \ldots, p_{n-k} \}$
be a finite sequence of points in ${\mathbb R}^k$.
We may study the shape of $P$ by studying the persistence diagram of a function $f : {\mathbb R}^k \to {\mathbb R}$ dependent on $P$, 
for example $f(x) = \min_{p \in P} || x - p ||_2$.
However, there is more structure.
The forward shift $p_i \to p_{i+1}$ along the sequence should induce dynamics near $P$ in ${\mathbb R}^k$.
The algebraic object of study is not clear, but it will certainly have more structure than an abelian group.

\section{Krull-Schmidt}
\label{sec:krull_schmidt}


Let ${\mathsf{C}}$ be an abelian category.
An object $a \in {\mathsf{C}}$ is \emph{indecomposable} if it is not the direct sum of two non-zero objects.

\begin{defn}
The category ${\mathsf{C}}$ is {\bf Krull-Schmidt} if each object $a \in {\mathsf{C}}$ is isomorphic to a finite direct sum
$a \cong a_1 \oplus a_2 \oplus \cdots \oplus a_n$, where each ring of endomorphisms ${\mathsf{End}}_{\mathsf{C}}(a_i)$ is local.
That is, if a finite sum $f_1 + f_2 + \cdots + f_m$ in ${\mathsf{End}}_{\mathsf{C}}(a_i)$ is an isomorphism, then one of the terms is an isomorphism.
\end{defn}


\begin{prop}
\label{prop:local_ring}
An object $a \in {\mathsf{C}}$ is indecomposable iff its endomorphism ring ${\mathsf{End}}(a)$ is local.
\end{prop}
\begin{proof}
Suppose $a \in {\mathsf{C}}$ is decomposable.
That is, there is an isomorphism $i :a \to a_1 \oplus a_2$ such that $a_1,a_2 \neq 0$.
Define $\pi_1 : a_1 \oplus a_2 \to a_1 \oplus a_2$ 
as the endomorphism that sends the first factor to zero
and $\pi_2 : a_1 \oplus a_2 \to a_1 \oplus a_2$ as the endomorphism that sends the second factor to zero.
Then the two maps $\rho_1, \rho_2 : a \to a$, where $\rho_1 = i^{-1} \circ \pi_1 \circ i$ and $\rho_2 = i^{-1} \circ \pi_2 \circ i$,
are both non-isomorphisms in ${\mathsf{End}}_{\mathsf{C}}(a)$.
However, $\rho_0 + \rho_1 :a \to a$ is an isomorphism.
We have a contradiction of locality.

Suppose $a \in {\mathsf{C}}$ is indecomposable.
Then, by definition of a Krull-Schmidt category, ${\mathsf{End}}_{\mathsf{C}}(a)$ is a local ring.
\end{proof}



\begin{prop}
Each object $a \in {\mathsf{C}}$ is isomorphic to a finite direct sum of indecomposables.
\end{prop}
\begin{proof}
By definition of a Krull-Schmidt category, $a \cong a_1 \oplus a_2 \oplus \cdots \oplus a_n$ where each
${\mathsf{End}}_{\mathsf{C}}(a_i)$ is a local ring.
By Proposition \ref{prop:local_ring}, each $a_i$ is indecomposable.
\end{proof}

\begin{thm}[Krull-Schmidt]
Suppose an object $c \in {\mathsf{Auto}}$ is isomorphic to $a_1 \oplus a_2 \oplus \cdots \oplus a_m$ and $b_1 \oplus b_2 \oplus \cdots \oplus b_n$,
where each $a_i$ and $b_j$ are indecomposable.
Then $m = n$, and there is a permutation $p: [m] \to [n]$ such that $a_i \cong b_{p(i)}$.
\end{thm}
\begin{proof}
By definition of an additive category, 
we have canonical projections $\pi_i : \oplus_i a_i \to a_i$ and $\rho_j : \oplus_j b_j \to b_j$ and canonical inclusions
$\mu_i : a_i \to \oplus_i a_i$ and $\nu_j : b_j \to \oplus_j b_j$.
Furthermore, $\mu_j \circ \pi_i$ and
$\nu_j \circ \rho_i$ are the identity on $a_i$ and $b_i$, respectively, iff $i = j$.
Let $f : a_1 \oplus a_2 \oplus \cdots \oplus a_m \to b_1 \oplus b_2 \oplus \cdots \oplus b_n$ be an isomorphism.

Define $h_j : a_1 \to a_1$ as $h_j = \pi_1 \circ f^{-1} \circ   \nu_j \circ \rho_j  \circ f \circ \mu_1$.
Let $h = \sum_j h_j: a_1 \to a_1$.
Observe $h$ is an isomorphism.
By locality, there is an index $j$ such that $h_j$ is an isomorphism.
This means $a_1 \cong b_j$ and we specify $p(1) = j$.
Quotient out by $a_1$ and $b_j$. Repeat.
\end{proof}
